top_comment.text:
I am surprised they never mentioned oil, which was a key military objective 
in both theaters of the war. The Japanese originally attacked Pearl Harbor 
to prevent the US Navy from impeding their conquest of the oil fields of 
the Dutch East Indies. This was mainly due to their lack of oil after the 
US started a trade embargo after the Japanese attacked China. In the west, 
the Germans were desperate for oil. The entire North Africa campaign had 
the single objective of the Suez Canal, to stop oil shipments from the 
Middle East to the UK and to get in on that oil themselves. After Operation 
Barbarossa failed in the winter of 1941, the Germans launched a new summer 
offensive (Case Blau) to take the oilfields of the Caucasus, and one 
important industrial city on the Volga, Stalingrad. World War II may have 
had origins in solidifying internal food production, but once the war was 
underway, the objective was oil. This truly was the first major war over 
oil, happening over half a century ago.﻿
top_comment.author: _notarealyoutubeaccount

comments.text:
+Melon Lord Yes food caused the war, but oil drove the war's outcome. Oil 
caused Axis powers to give only limited training to mobile fighting 
personnel, especially aircraft fighter pilots. Although Axis planes were 
still quite effective in the hands of able pilots, few new pilots received 
adequate training to ensure success. Furthermore, oil drove logistical 
problems that destroyed the Axis war machine, especially in Germany. World 
War 2 was a war caused by food, but driven by oil. This is the problem with 
modern academics, they like to focus on the cause of war and the results of 
the war, but relatively little of what actually happened in the war. For 
instance, we all learn what caused World War 2 and the war's results. We 
learn that the Germans were in Stalingrad in 1942, and the Japanese 
attacked Pearl Harbor in 1941, but we never learn why. We learn that the 
Soviets lost 20 million people in World War 2, but we never learn that 
nearly 25% of those casualties were caused by other Russians. We learn that 
poison gas was used in World War 1, but we never hear the story about the 
young German corporal, blinded by gas in 1918, who vowed to give up his 
fruitless ventures in art and architecture and enter politics if he would 
ever regain his sight. That young German would help start National 
Socialist German Workers' Party, which would later be abbreviated to the 
Nazi Party and come under the control of that corporal, Adolf Hitler. See, 
just knowing the cause and results of war doesn't paint the entire picture. 
To understand the full impact of the war, you have to understand the war 
itself. To just glance over the  war part of the war, claiming that its 
unimportant, is to leaving out the most important thing you are trying to 
teach. The results of the war are based on what happened in the war, not 
just the causes. Without all three parts, beginning, middle, and end, you 
will never truly understand what happened.
comments.author: _notarealyoutubeaccount

comments.text:
What I mean is that yes, it was a war for resources, where previous wars 
were for glory, yet I don't see any war from previous history which has 
only been for glory: all have been, to my knowledge, for the taking of land 
for their resources.

But the failure of how wars are often explained and detailed is that they, 
as John pus it so eloquently quite often, the truth resists simplicity. The 
complexity of these wars as to whom bears the mantle of "bad guy" and "good 
guy" is prickly, even today. While the general consensus is that Hitler was 
the bad guy from WWII, the Russians kind of were the ones who killed the 
most foreigners, the Japanese did the sneakiest attacks, and the US was the 
one who dropped the fucking A bomb (being where the term "Fucking A!" came 
from). The Germans took over Poland and other countries for resources to 
fulfill their political obligations, but their methods were horrendous and 
barbaric, and their delineation as to who was deserving of their spoils was 
flatly disgusting.

But this was nothing new. Their doing this was exactly the same as warlord 
of the history books who're often admired and revered for their warrior 
prowess. The differences are really only twofold:
1. The Americans had television, and thus were able to stage a propaganda 
campaign against Hitler. Accurately, largely, but present nonetheless. In 
the past, rallying the troops was all that was required, but in the new 
world of television and cinema news at the talkies, this gave more drive to 
patriotism than ever before, and for a country such as the United States 
who wasn't even *fucking involved* to have such a campaign is still 
baffling to my mind. Sure, the English probably couldn't have beaten the 
Germans on their own, but had they approached the situation without the 
Americans in tow, surely they'd have pulled more ranks in from India and 
Australia, given we're both their colonies.
2. Hitler used propaganda for the common-folk. It's believed that of the 
estimated 6 million Jews who were killed in Germany during WWII and the 
Holocaust, close to half a million of these were straight up homicides: 
people being murdered by their neighbours. This was being encouraged and 
propagated by the German media. When 1/12 of your victims are murdered by 
commonday people because you tell them to on television, it means your 
tactics are working, mercilessly and with the worst smattering of an 
insidious tone than ever before.

But do you know the war that rages on today that is exactly like this? The 
war on drugs. Demonising people who use drugs so as to put them in prison 
and making them considered evil is one of the reasons America is the worst 
country in the world right now. Even all of the places in the world you 
could say are "bad" places don't imprison more of their own people than the 
USA, and most don't campaign on television to tell people just how bad 
their habits are. The reason you're losing this war is because you've 
called it a war. Simple.

comments.author: Planeswalker123

comments.text:
+Planeswalker123 Yeah, propaganda played the biggest roll, pretty much. The 
Japanese preached to their men that the Americans murdered Japanese POWs. 
They were then too afraid to get captured.

Iwo Jima was proof that the Japanese did not need to commit suicide charges 
to cause some problems to the enemy. The Kamikazi was only effective 
because it was a loss of 1 man, 1 plane, and several hundred pounds of 
explosives for an entire vessel, which is a really good payoff, especially 
given how the men are not phased to embark on such a mission due to 
"Bushido" propaganda. However, the Banzai charge was a payment of too many 
men for too few targets. General Kuribayashi (I am sure I spelled his name 
wrong) ordered the men of Iwo Jima NOT to die until they killed 10 men 
each. Of course, no promises could be kept, but it basically meant he would 
not tolerate suicide charges. If each man could fight longer, they were 
ordered to, which really put Kuribayashi in a bad political position.

For Japanese politics, they didn't want the men and people to know that 
they were losing the war. If the men were to suicide, they would not be 
affected by the poor moral of crushing defeats. Furthermore they would not 
spread defeatist notions in the home islands. It was only when the war hit 
Okinawa (when the most Japanese prisoners were captured) that people gave 
up and just outright admitted that the war was coming to the homeland.

In Okinawa, women committed suicide, which I think would be a whole new 
situation. It is not an irrational fear for a woman to fear the men of an 
occupying army. History only shows that EVERY occupying army has to deal 
with its own men mistreating or raping the women of the occupied territory. 
However, it further shows how much the Japanese government put an emphasis 
on death over defeat, because Chinese women did not commit mass suicide 
when the Japanese invaded, and neither did Soviet women, or German women. 
The fear is normal, but the action was very strange, even for the culture 
(as Japanese women are not bound by the code of Bushido).

Japanese adjust their tactics knowing how well the Americans were armed 
compared to the Chinese? Yea the thing you said about lack of technology 
makes sense the comment i made was more referring to the bayonet charges of 
the Japanese infantry but i'm skeptical about the amount that propaganda 
had any influence on their battle tactics and i don't think its too far

comments.author: Planeswalker123

comments.text:
Not really. The Banzai charge was actually a military tactic that was 
effective against Chinese soldiers, because it instilled fear and worked 
well against low rate-of-fire bolt action rifles. They thought it would 
work against the Americans, even though almost every American had at least 
a semi-automatic weapon excluding the Marines on Guadalcanal, but it failed 
miserably. They kept doing it because Japanese propaganda depicted that 
Americans treated POW's the same way the Japanese did. Even though some 
American soldiers did some very very disturbing things to some Japanese 
soldiers (boiling their skulls to use as hood ornaments), for the most part 
the Americans treated Japanese POW's well.

The Kamikazi was an answer to the need for a guided weapon to make up for 
the lack of heavy ordnance. Since they did not have the technology for heat 
seeking or remote controlled rockets (even though they had a prototype 
remote controlled tank), they resorted to manned missiles (zeroes, and 
later there were designs to use actual jets and rockets with pilots). It 
was effective because of the Japanese Bushido code, as the Germans brought 
the idea first (they thought of German pilots dying for the Fatherland, but 
knew that nobody would voluntarily suicide-crash into a ship, so then they 
decided that pilots should destroy other planes by clipping them with their 
wings and bailing, but that was also stupid).

Food didn't cause anything. If you are starving, you have no energy for a 
bayonet charge. Besides, starvation is not glorious, so it tends to not get 
talked about in war, because getting shot or exploding is more glamorous 
than starving.

comments.text:
+HK Normann I guess it really boils down to tough choices in a hard time, 
and people honestly believed what they did was the right thing to do.

The atom bomb? Generals like Patton did not want the bomb dropped because 
they believed it was dishonorable (the Japanese would have agreed), but 
others believed saving military lives was the right thing to do. The choice 
of a civilian target was a tactical one, as it would destroy moral. Japan's 
economy had already tanked, so bombing a military target would not have 
mattered. It wasn't black and white on the Japanese side either. Yamamoto 
did not want a war against the US because he knew the Japanese would lose. 
He wanted peace as soon as possible. Others wanted peace after hearing the 
threat of an apocalyptic bomb. The militarists trusted Japanese tenacity 
enough to believe taking the bombs face first and continuing the war was 
the right thing to do because there was a small chance Japan could scrape a 
conditional surrender.

Look at Hitler and Stalin. Hitler didn't do anything he did because he was 
the spawn of Satin like short minded people like to believe (which is why I 
compare him to Attila the Hun because he was also viewed as the spawn of 
Satin, the "Scourge of God" in the immediate future after his exploits). He 
did what he did because he believed it was the right thing to do. If you 
honestly believe your economy is being sabotaged by one race, you kill them 
off. It makes sense, until the notion that their belief was wrong comes up 
(likewise just because someone believes something doesn't make it actually 
good, as 6 million Jews and 12 million Russians would agree). Stalin's 
Gulag system was also under the belief that everything he did was right, 
and if you think logically under the assumption that you ARE infallible, 
arresting any opposition IS the right thing to do. He had Russia in his 
mind first.

Good intentions pave the the road to hell, and there should be more 
forgiveness for those who WEREN'T politicians as they were put in extreme 
pressure. However, people should just stop worrying who the bad guys and 
good guys were in WWII and worry more about doing the right thing today, 
especially when decisions will still be very difficult to make. Do you drop 
the bomb to save your own men, comrades, friends, and family, or do you not 
drop the bomb to save the innocent lives of your enemies civilians?

captions.text:
Hi, I’m John Green and this is Crash Course
World History and today we’re going to talk

about World War II.
But we’re not going to look at it as a battle

between good and evil, but instead as a war
for resources, particularly a war for food.

Wait, Mr. Green, Mr. Green, what about like Rosie the
Riveter and Pearl Harbor and Nazis and Hitler?
Yeah, Me From the Past, I mean if the question is was

Hitler evil? Then, yeah.
But evil people generally can’t, like, cause

massive world wars on their own. So instead of talking
about, uh, you know, the personality driven model

of history, I want to talk about resources,
specifically my favorite resource: food.

So the story of World War 2 is commonly told
as a narrative of good vs. evil, and it is.

But we can also look at the second world war
through the lens of resource allocation, and

I think if we do it tells a story of both
causes of the war and one of the ways that

it impacted both soldiers and civilians.
The presence or absence of food affected everyone

involved in World War II. In the most stark
terms, the absence of food led to the deaths,

directly or indirectly, of at least 20 million
people during those years, as compared to
19.5 million military deaths.

Now, of course, both the Nazis and the Japanese
were militaristic and expansionist in the

1930s.
And they were both definitely motivated by

nationalism, but they were also seeking something
called autarky.

You can remember this term by conjuring the
feeling one gets near Thanksgiving: “Aw,

turkey”.
You can also remember it when thinking about

the collapse of the Ottoman Empire: “Aw,
Turkey”.

Anyway, autarky is a form of self sufficiency
in a world where, increasingly, people were

reliant on world trade, and that made nations
more and more dependent upon each other to

meet basic needs.
Both Germany and Japan lacked the resources

within their borders that they needed to build
their growing industrial states, and the resource

that concerned them most was food.
And this was a big part of what motivated

their imperialist expansionism.
Like, Hitler talked all the time about expanding

German territory to acquire “lebensraum,”
or living space.

But what this meant, of course, was agricultural
land to feed Germans, that’s what living

space is really about on Earth.
And most Germans of the time remembered the

blockade during World War I, which had led
to acute food shortages.

For the Nazis, to quote Collingham, “Lebensraum
would make Germany truly self-sufficient and

immune to blockade and this would eventually
enable Germany to challenge British and American

hegemony.”
Meanwhile, in Japan the need for food was

also spurring imperial ambitions. If anything,
Japan’s limited space created a sense of

crisis and made colonies seem necessary.
Like Japanese colonies in Korea and Formosa,

taken in the Sino-Japanese war of 1894-1895,
provided 20% of the Japanese domestic rice

crop by 1935.
And then the Great Depression and Japan’s

growing population made the situation appear
even worse and probably led to the decision

to annex Manchuria after 1931.
So the Germans’ plan was to open up Poland,

and eventually parts of Russia, to German
farmers. The Japanese plan was to resettle

farmers in Manchuria to provide food for the
homeland.

So if the desire for more food was one of
the initial causes of World War 2, it also

shaped the actual strategy of the war.
This was especially true with one of the stupidest

decisions of the war, Hitler’s decision
to invade the Soviet Union.

A German agronomist named Hans Backe put forth
something called “the Hunger Plan”, and

in doing so convinced Hitler that in order
to become self-sufficient, Germany had to

invade the Soviet Union.
And everyone knows that you cannot successfully
invade Russia unless you are the Mongols.

Anyway, the plan was the Ukraine and western
Russia would be transformed into a huge breadbasket

that would feed both the German armies and
German civilians. This was never fully implemented,

because, you know, the Nazi’s could never
successfully nail down all of the territory,

but Collingham argues that it was a primary
motive for Hitler’s disastrous invasion of the USSR.

And then on the Western front, the so called
“Battle of the Atlantic” was largely about

shipping arms, material, and food from the
U.S. to Britain.

This was incredibly important in the opening
years of World War 2. Like, Winston Churchill

once said that “the Battle of the Atlantic
was the dominating factor all through the

war. Never for one moment could we forget
that everything happening elsewhere, on land,

at sea or in the air, depended ultimately
on its outcome.”

In short, it was Britain’s dependence upon
other parts of the world that ultimately made

it stronger than Germany’s attempts at self-sufficiency.
Starvation never became an issue for the Brits,

but fear of running out of food, especially
of running out of food for the troops, led

to policies that made starvation a reality
for many people in British colonies.

In British Africa, for instance, colonial
policy forcing production for the war instead

of for domestic food consumption meant shortages
that were only made worse by wartime inflation.

Crop failure in Rhodesia in 1942 meant widespread
hunger and famine.

And, in an echo of what happened at the end
of the 19th century, World War II and British

colonial policy spelled disaster for India.
Japan had seized Burma in early 1942, cutting

off 15% of Bengal’s rice supply.
And when harvests failed later that year,

hunger turned to famine. Now, the British
could have alleviated the suffering but they were

afraid to use supply ships that might be needed
for the war effort to bring food to starving

people in India.
When you take into account hunger-associated

diseases, between 1.5 and 3 million Indian
civilians died, more than the total number

of Indian combatants killed in World War 1
AND World War 2 combined.

In the United States, meanwhile, there was
no starvation, but there was some rationing.

And this was, especially relative to most
recent American wars, some shared sacrifice.

Americans gave up coffee and chocolate so
that the troops could be well fed.

So Americans and Britons hardly suffered from
hunger. Neither did the Germans, actually,

where memories of World War I made feeding
the civilian population a top priority.

Of course, millions of civilians weren’t
being fed because they were being murdered

or worked to death in concentration camps.
But in Britain, World War II might have actually

improved people’s diets. Now, Britons largely
despised the whole-meal National Loaf of bread,

but it was more nutritious than white bread
and its flour took up less cargo space.

It’s amazing to think that British people
would dislike good food when there’s so

much of it in their country.
Stan, this is the part where in the comments

all the British people say, “We are not
a country, we’re four separate countries!”

The “dig for victory” campaign encouraged
ordinary people to plant gardens, and so they

ate more vegetables. Full employment and higher
wages meant that working class people also

had more access to nutritious foods.
Also, you know, they had the benefit of Canada

growing like, a gajillion acres of wheat.
Although both the British and the Germans saw

an overall reduction in caloric intake, it
was nothing compared with what was happening

in the USSR, Japan and China. In Russia, daily
caloric intake by the end of the war was half

of what it had been in 1940.
And I will remind you that things were not

great in 1940 in Russia, because Stalin.
The daily caloric ration for Japanese women

workers fell to 1476 calories, which was bad,
but in China, where the corrupt Nationalist army

was known to sell rice to the Japanese for
profit, a famine in Guangdong claimed the

lives of as many as 1.5 million peasants.
And without doubt, much of the civilian suffering

in the war was related to the massive amounts
of food needed to keep soldiers fighting.
Let’s go to the Thought Bubble.

In World War 2, the US and Britain made a
massive effort to make sure that their soldiers

were well fed, and for the most part it paid
off, even though the food that they got was

sometimes pretty gross. The British World
War I diet of biscuits and bully beef eventually

gave way to the appetizingly named “composite
ration.” American soldiers may have complained

a lot about their infamous C and K rations, but
they were the best fed soldiers in the world, receiving

a whopping 4,758 calories per day, including
meat at every meal, because, you know… America.

As you can probably guess, Soviet soldiers
did not fare so well, especially when the

Germans invaded because it was their policy
to live off the land, which meant scrounging

as much food from the Russian countryside
as they could. German troops weren’t as

well fed as Americans or the Brits, but they
still managed to scarf down a respectable
4000 calories per day.

No combat soldiers were as consistently hungry,
however, as the Japanese. Japanese soldiers

were expected to feed themselves and were
not provided with field kitchens. Often this

meant that Japanese soldiers were fueled by
little more than rice. And as the war turned

against them it became more and more difficult
for Japanese troops to feed themselves.

On Guadalcanal the Japanese attempted to re-supply
their troops with floating barrels dropped

from passing ships, but by December 1942 between
120 and 130 soldiers were dying of starvation

every day. The Japanese commander there estimated
that while 5000 of his soldiers died in combat,

15,000 starved to death. Overall, it’s estimated
that more than 1 million of the 1.74 million

Japanese military deaths were caused by starvation
or malnutrition.

Thanks Thought Bubble. So, a quick look at
the history section in your local bookstore

or an IMDB search will tell you that there
are hundreds if not thousands of ways to tell

the story of World War II.
And this is just one history of the war, certainly

not a definitive one.
But examining the role of resources, especially

food, in the second world war tells a story
that has at least one advantage over the narrative

of the triumph of Allied good over Axis evil.
Because it helps us to see that the war was

not only about the soldiers fighting, and
it gives us a window into the way the war
affected everyone who lived at the time.

It also allows us to see World War II from
a global perspective in a way that focusing

on strategy or tactics or pivotal battles
doesn’t.

Like very little fighting went on in Sub-Saharan
Africa or most of India, but these places

were deeply affected by the war in ways that
don’t often make it into history books.

Also, we live today in a thoroughly globalized
world, but so did the people of the 1930s,

and it’s very interesting to see some of
their responses to it.

That hyper nationalist idea, that we can take
care of ourselves and don’t need help from

outside, as long as we annex a lot of territory
that’s currently outside of us - that idea

is a response to globalization.
But I think history shows us that it’s a

horrible response.
It’s a dangerous business when humans imagine

others as less, when they think their land
needs to become our land so we can feed our

people.
And in that sense at least, you can’t separate

ideology from resource allocation, and as
long as we live in a world of finite resources,

the potential for conflict will always be
there. Knowing that, hopefully, will help

us to avoid it. Thanks for watching. I’ll
see you next week.

Crash Course is filmed here in the Chad and
Stacey Emigholz studio and it's made with the

help of all of these nice people and also
with the help of our Subbable subscribers.

Subbable is a voluntary subscription service
that allows you to contribute directly to

Crash Course so we can continue its mission
of keeping it free for everyone forever. So

thank you for making Crash Course possible,
thanks for watching, and as we say in my hometown,
don’t forget to be awesome.

title: World War II, A War for Resources: Crash Course World History #220
